sentences: Hayes was well known during television's golden age as the unnamed boyfriend opposite his real-real-life wife Peggy Ann Garner to Barbara "Babs" Smith on the ABC sitcom Two Girls Named Smith for two seasons in 1951.
Born in Brooklyn, New York, on January 5, 1930, Hayes had much success as a recording artist while in his late teens.
Between 1948 and 1953, Hayes had fourteen top 25 hits.
His most successful record was his rendition of The Old Master Painter which was released in 1949.
The song, produced by Mitch Miller, reached no. 2 on the national charts in December 1949 and remained on the charts for twelve weeks until March 1950.
The song, produced by Mitch Miller, reached no. 2 on the national charts in December 1949 and remained on the charts for twelve weeks until March 1950.
After leaving Contempo in 1964, Hayes pursued a further career in television making several appearances on The Ed Sullivan Show and The Robert Q. Lewis Show.
Hayes also was a regular guest on Arthur Godfrey's television and radio series between 1958 and 1972.
He was drafted into the military, (Army specifically), in 1953.
He served during the Korean War which ended in June 1953, a few months after Hayes' conscription, and the Cold War.
The fact that he was in the army and his musical/acting background, Hayes earned a permanent spot as the emcee and co-host with Arlene Francis on the ABC competition series Soldier Parade in 1954.
He remained on the show until its cancellation in June 1955.
In the 1970s, Hayes retired from acting and became a game show host.
Several game shows he hosted include the syndicated version of Name That Tune from 1970–71 and All About Faces.
He also worked as a talk-radio host at several radio stations in Philadelphia and New York City before retiring in 1990.
Hayes died on March 10, 2014 at the age of 84 in his home in Los Angeles, California after battling a long illness.
Richard Herbert Hayes was born on January 5, 1930 in Brooklyn, New York.
Hayes was discovered by a personnel from Mercury Records in 1948.
The next song he recorded for the Mercury label was a version of the song "My Foolish Heart" in 1950.
But the fifth song he recorded, a duet with Kitty Kallen entitled "Our Lady Of Fatima", managed to reach number 10 on the charts beginning in September 1950 and remained there for three months.
In March 1951, Hayes recorded another duet with Kallen entitled "The Aba Daba Honeymoon".
During the summer of 1951 Hayes recorded a version of Nat King Cole's hit "Too Young" on the Mercury label.
Hayes' next hit came in May 1952 with the tune "I'll Walk Alone" which, despite a number of versions including the big hit version by Don Cornell, Hayes' recording got to number 24.
Both of the songs were recorded in 1952, the latter being ranked number 15 on the charts.
Hayes' last hit song with Mercury was entitled "Midnight in Paris", recorded in the summer of 1953 with The Richard Hayman Orchestra, which was a top twenty-five seller.
Hayes left Mercury Records in 1954 in hopes of joining Columbia Records where Miller had gone four years earlier.

He remained with the series until its cancellation in 1955 and left the military that same year.
Hayes also made frequent appearances on Arthur Godfrey's radio and television programs between 1958 and 1972.
Shortly after the release of his last record in 1964, Hayes worked on several game shows.
He first spent several years at WMCA in New York, then went to WWDB in Philadelphia, and from there to WCAU 1210am (now WPHT), where he stayed until 1990.
Garner and Hayes divorced in 1953.
Hayes died on March 10, 2014 in Los Angeles, California after battling a long illness.
In the late 1970s, Hayes moved back to New York where he became a congenial radio host.
He also was the host of the Canadian syndicated hidden camera game show All About Faces from 1971-1972.
From 1970-1971, Hayes was the host of the syndicated version of the game show Name That Tune.
He first worked as an announcer on the original ABC game show Supermarket Sweep from 1965-1967, followed by a stint as host of the 1967-1968 series The Baby Game.
Hayes also made frequent guest star appearances on The Ed Sullivan Show and The Robert Q. Lewis Show between 1956-1964.
He served during the last few months of the Korean War.
Hayes was originally married to actress Peggy Ann Garner from 1951-1953.
Between 1948-1949, Hayes made three recordings for Mercury that weren't that successful.

Mercury Records (1948-54)
